children.subject:
Thanks for your reply. Am very sorry, but Professor Sahai not being a great teacher is not what I meant. I meant to say his class requires more rigor, and that his homeworks are obviously very difficult. I have already edited the post to better reflect what I meant. Otherwise, Sahai is definitely one of the best, if not the  best professors at teaching here at Cal. Hell, I took him for EE16A this semester, and he was nothing short of amazing, both as a teacher, and as someone who cares deeply about his students. So, yes, I agree with you in that he is indeed a terrific professor! Am sorry that my post was a little bit misleading.
Also, thank you for the links to his cs70 webcasts, because I couldn't find them on the course website.

Good luck! I remembered Sahai recommended two books that are just helpful in general (CS70 and beyond):

- How to Solve it by Polya

- How to Prove it by Velleman

Same Anon here:

If you want to more coding practice, summer 61b is lab-based. That means they give a lot of reading and practice (more than regular 61b) in lab. They give more detailed explanation of concepts and code implementation. Checkout:

http://www.cs61bl.org/su17/

Just a comment on "but at least they're not as bad as Sahai":

Sahai's lecture is the best among the eecs profs. Although his homework is really challenging, that does not mean his lecture is bad. Here's how you can prep for it: go to webcast.berkeley.edu and watch Sahai's CS70 lecture. His lecturing is extremely well done. Most importantly, his lecture has a clear story line. 

For CS61B:

http://datastructur.es/sp17/ has all the material (webcast, homework, everything) you need.

For 61B, I would recommend:

  1. Finding ways to get comfortable with Java syntax so you have more time to get used to it. You've already seen the big conceptual ideas in 61A such as iteration, recursion, linkedlists, object oriented programming, etc., so first many people, the first sliver of the course is a rough scramble to recall these ideas while everything looks syntactically different. Perhaps give the recommend readings in Head First Java a look.
  2. Watching some old lectures. I'm personally a fan of Shewchuk's. You can find them at https://coursecapture.berkeley.edu/compsci-61b. Hearing ideas from one perspective here and then from another during the lectures in the upcoming semester will hopefully increase your comprehensive understanding.
If you'd like another freshmen to study with over break, hmu at v.attre@berkeley.edu

history.content:
Quick comment - I had Babak for EE 16A and EE 120, and he is an EXCELLENT lecturer. You have nothing to worry about there.

Re: preparing for both classes, if you're familiar with basic Java syntax before diving into 61B, you'll be in good shape. Run through some online tutorials (codecademy is fine) and if you want to go further check out the previous 61B lectures themselves. For 70, most of my classmates struggled with developing the basic intuition for probability, so I'd recommend focusing on that. Again, previous lectures and notes will be your best friend - 70's a very unique class and you'd be hard-pressed to find quite that combination of topics anywhere else. Good luck!

Hello everyone,

So, i'll be taking these two classes next semester, and I was looking to self-study them over the break. Basically, I just want to have a leg up, and a better understanding of the material before school resumes on the fall. Ultimately, i'm looking to get A's in these classes next semester(I know this is not the sole purpose of learning, but I really want a solid understanding of this classes since i'll be diving straight into upper-divs after this.) How would you guys go about it?
Am in EECS, so it's not even me being worried about declaring, but rather having a SOLID understanding of the concepts in these courses.

I've downloaded all the CS70 material, including Homeworks (+solutions), and Discussions(+solutions), and I can say the same for CS61B except for the projects, which I heard change from semester to semester. Hug's going to be teaching it, and i've heard really great things about him. Satish Rao, and Babak will be teaching CS70 (I haven't heard great things about them as teachers, but atleast their homework's are not as hard as Sahai's)

Any hindsight + advice on this?
history.subject: Preparing for CS70+CS61B over Winter break
